articles.title: Dissemination
articles.contents:
Expert Advisory
Member of expert group for Transparency International Denmark’s
In May 2021, I was invited to join Transparency International Denmark’s network of Danish researchers who have expertise related to corruption and abuse of power. Description in Danish here.

Oral dissemination of research
Research presentation, Transparency International Denmark, May 2021
Presentation about my research field for the board of Transparency International Denmark. Further, I provided my inputs and discussed how to mitigate corruption and malfeasance in the Danish municipalities in relation to the (at that point) upcoming municipality election in November 2021.
Research presentation at Projekt Forskerspirer, April 2021
Presentation about my research and reseach designs for the social science section in Projekt Forskerspirer (Junior Researchers Project) – a program where academically talented high school students learn to conduct research

Written dissemination of research
Politiken, June 29 2021: ”Pia overbeviser liges˚a godt som Per, n˚ar hun udtaler sig som ekspert” with Katrine Greve-Poulsen, Rasmus Tue Pedersen and Erik Albæk.
Article disseminating the results of our research article ”No Gender Bias in Audience Perceptions of Male and Female Experts in the News: Equally Competent and Persuasive” in the Danish newspaper Politiken.
Danish URL here
Uniavisen/The University Post, June 25 2021: ”New study: Readers perceive male and female experts as equally competent”.
My co-author Katrine Greve-Poulsen and I were interviewed about our first academic publication by University of Copenhagen’s independent news paper Uniavisen (The University Post).
English version here, Danish version here.

            Welcome to my website. Thanks for stopping by! I am a PhD Fellow at Department of Political Science, University of Copenhagen and Visiting Fellow at Department of Government, Harvard University.
            My research revolves around politicians private benefits and downsides of serving in office and what this means for the composition of the political class, i.e. its’ quality and representation. I study this in Denmark and am delighted to work with rich registry data from the Danish authorities. I deploy various types of quasi-experiments and traditional experiments to derive credible conclusions about the realm of politics.
            My PhD is supervised by Professor Lene Holm Pedersen and Assistant Professor Jens Olav Dahlgaard and my Visiting Fellowship at Harvard is sponsored by Professor James Snyder.

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
Here you can find my research – published articles (yes, okay there’s only one for now) as well as stuff I am working on at the moment. Reach out to me at fkl[at]ifs[dot]ku[dot]dk if want to a copy of one of my working papers.

Published work
Greve-Poulsen, K., Larsen, F. K., Pedersen, R. T., & Albæk, E. (2021). No Gender Bias in Audience Perceptions of Male and Female Experts in the News: Equally Competent and Persuasive. The International Journal of Press/Politics, OnlineFirst.
Open Access version
Code and replication data

Work in progress
Reward or Punishment? The Distribution of Returns to Political Office with Jens Olav Dahlgaard and Nicolai Kristensen
We estimate the economic returns to winning office focusing on close winning and losing candidates running for Danish national elections. We devote special attention to 1) effect heterogeneity among candidates with different pre-office income potentials and 2) the timing of returns to office, as some economic consequences of holding office occur immediately when entering office while others occur later in life.

Do Elected Women Candidates Foster Increased Female Political Representation? with Jens Olav Dahlgaard, Benjamin Egerod and Lene Holm Pedersen.
We investigate if the election of a woman for office foster female representation in future elections and beyond the candidate herself. We do this by focusing on local elections, where a woman marginally wins a seat over a man competing for the same seat, and estimate what this means to the composition of the future candidate pools and thus how it shapes the supply of political candidates.

Amateurs in office: What Are the Returns to a Part-time Political Office?
I estimate how holding a part-time political office affect income and civil career of Danish local councilors. Concerning the latter, I specifically investigate what being a local councilor do to the councilors labour supply and probability of being promoted conditional on sector of employment.

Does Policy Motivation Shape Political Careers? Evidence from a Quasi-Experiment
I estimate the effect of increased policy discretion on incumbents’ decision to rerun for office to test how policy motivation affect political careers.

Government Ideology and Gender Equality in Public Sector Promotions with Lasse Aaskoven and Benjamin Egerod
We estimate how women’s career progression in the Danish bureaucracy depend on the ideology of the government in office.

The Price of Power: Politicians’ Trade-Off Between Political Power, Remuneration, Time-Consumption and (Non-Sexistic) Work Environment in Local Governments with Lene Holm Pedersen
We investigate how political candidates’ trade-off four important dimensions of holding political office, namely 1) political power, 2) remuneration, 3) work load and 4) quality of work environment. We study this by using a conjoint-choice experiment fielded among the political candidates in the Danish municipal election in November 2021.

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
Courses taught
Public Policy, Department of Political Science, University of Copenhagen, Spring 2020, 2021, 2022
Cohort lecturing appr. 200 undergraduate students three weeks in a row on topics like political rent-seeking, regulatory capture and blame-avoidance.

Methods 3, Department of Political Science, University of Copenhagen, Spring 2020 and 2021
Taught classes of appr. 35 undergraduate students on topics like experimental designs, quasi-experimental designs and panel data estimation.

Methods 1, Department of Political Science, University of Copenhagen, Spring 2018
Taught a weekly class of appr. 35 undergraduate students, carried out sections and workshops in applied methods and statistics.

Bachelor Thesis Methods Sessions, Department of Political Science, University of Copenhagen, Spring 2018
Helped students with methodological and statistical concerns in their bachelor theses throughout the semester.

Short courses/workshops
Quasi-experimental analyses in R, Department of Psychology, University of Cambridge, May 2021
2 hour tutorial session for PhD students about regression discontinuity designs and difference-in-differences designs and how to implement it in R.
